fields.message: We know waiting for answers can be stressful. This report summarizes what we’ve learned so far and what comes next so you can feel informed and supported.

sections.title: Your Diagnosis

fields.diagnosis_summary: Your results show early-stage breast cancer: Invasive Ductal Carcinoma, Estrogen positive, Progesterone positive (ER+/PR+), HER2 negative (IHC 2+, FISH negative), Nottingham grade 2.

tumors.title: Tumor 1
tumors.notes: Small tumor, less than a centimeter. Grade 2 is intermediate. Initial tests show no signs of spread to the lymph nodes.

whatThisMeans.goodNews: The tumor is small, and initial tests show no signs of spread to the lymph nodes, which is a positive sign for a successful outcome.
whatThisMeans.newOptions: A critical step will be the Oncotype DX score to help determine the need for chemotherapy.
whatThisMeans.treatmentFocus: The primary, highly effective long-term treatment will be anti-hormone pills (endocrine therapy) to 'starve' the cancer and keep it from returning for years.

sections.footer_note: This summary is based on your latest pathology and imaging reports.

items.name: Breast core needle biopsy
items.explanation: Tissue sample taken for pathology testing for ER/PR/HER2 status.

items.name: Medical Oncology Consultation
items.explanation: Meet with medical oncologist to review your results and discuss your treatment plan.

items.name: Surgical Oncology Consultation
items.explanation: Meet with surgical oncologist to discuss tumor removal options.

sections.title: Your Likely Treatments

fields.summary: Knowing your likely treatment plan helps you prepare for your first oncology visit.
fields.disclaimer: This overview reflects current clinical guidelines and may change based on new results.

treatments.name: Endocrine therapy (hormone therapy)
treatments.description: Most likely treatment given that you are hormone receptor positive (ER+ and PR+). This treatment 'starves' the cancer.
treatments.expected_timing: Typically started by the medical oncologist after surgery.

medications.name: Aromatase inhibitors
medications.description: Includes letrozole, anastrozole, or exemestane—pills that lower estrogen levels.

medications.name: Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulators
medications.description: Like tamoxifen — pills that block estrogen.

side_effects.description: Hot flashes, mild joint pain, and fatigue.

treatment_time.notes: Administered orally and continued long term depending on response.

treatments.name: Surgical Oncology
treatments.description: Likely required to fully remove the Invasive Ductal Carcinoma (8mm). Your choices will likely be either Lumpectomy or Mastectomy.

treatment_time.notes: The pros and cons of Lumpectomy vs. Mastectomy should be discussed with your surgeon.

treatments.name: Chemotherapy
treatments.description: This might be considered and will be dependent on the Oncotype DX score result.
treatments.expected_timing: Prior to or after surgery, depending on plan.

treatment_time.duration: To be determined by Oncotype DX

treatments.name: Radiation Oncology
treatments.description: This might be recommended if you and your surgeon choose a Lumpectomy (Breast-Conserving Surgery).

sections.disclaimer_footer: Your treatment plan may change as additional test results become available.

sections.title: Helpful Questions for Your Oncologist
sections.description: Bring these questions to your appointment to help guide your discussion.

questions.text: Given my specific tumor status (HR+/HER2-), how soon can the OncotypeDX test be ordered, and when can we expect the results? How will this single score determine my need for chemotherapy?
I am currently taking an Estrogen Patch and Progesterone Pill. Since my cancer is hormone receptor positive, what is the immediate risk of continuing this, and when exactly should I stop taking?

What specific anti-hormone medication (e.g., Tamoxifen or an Aromatase Inhibitor) do you recommend, and for how many years will I need to take it? What are the most common side effects of this medication?
If my OncotypeDX score is high, what chemotherapy regimen would you recommend, and how many cycles would that involve?
Given my tumor size (8 mm) and clear margins, am I a good candidate for Breast-Conserving Surgery (Lumpectomy)? What factors might require me to have a mastectomy instead?
My initial ultrasound was negative for lymph node involvement. Will I still need a Sentinel Lymph Node Biopsy (SLNB) during the surgery, and what happens if cancer is found in those nodes?
What is your goal for clear margins, and what is the chance I would need a second surgery to clear them (a re-excision)?
Since I am premenopausal and my treatment will include endocrine therapy, what is the impact on my future fertility, and should I meet with the fertility counselor immediately?
What is the likelihood of experiencing specific side effects, like hair loss, weight changes, or joint pain, with the systemic treatment you anticipate recommending?
What support services or medications are available here at the clinic for managing fatigue, hot flashes, or any emotional concerns related to my diagnosis and treatment?
What will the breast look like after surgery, and will a plastic surgeon be involved in my care?

sections.footer_note: Write down any additional questions before your next visit.
